text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single vertical column of two large circular medallions occupying most of the page, each medallion framed by concentric green and blue bands; wide outer borders decorated with foliate scrolls and micro-architectural panels; no visible running text interacting with the images; visual hierarchy given to the two roundels with equal size and placement, separated by a foliate quatrefoil filling the central gutter area.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf uniformly used as background to denote divine and sacred space; deep blue and red pigments alternate in figures’ draperies to create rhythmic visual emphasis; green used sparingly for foliage and mounts; white highlights applied over colored washes for modeling; layered application of opaque lead white for drapery folds; minimal pigment darkening indicates stable preservation.

features: Two-tier narrative layout with medallions stacked top to bottom
Vertical axis aligning central figures in both scenes
Circular framing creating self-contained narrative units
Smaller margin figures holding scroll-bands echoing main medallion scenes
Balanced distribution of figural groups left and right within each roundel

decorative_elements: Concentric circular frames with alternating blue and green bands
Outer border panels of stylized vine scrolls and grotesques
Micro-architectural cornerpieces with quatrefoil and foliate motifs
Inset demi-figures in each corner holding scrolls
White scroll-band motifs linking margin and medallion imagery

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold ink outlines defining figures and drapery, with finer internal hatch lines for detail; underdrawing visible in brown ink under UV.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat washes of color with subtle white-lead highlighting on garment folds; minimal parallel hatching for volume.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of figures by importance; shallow stage-like space indicated by overlapping figures and absence of convergent perspective.

reading_order: Top medallion first, then bottom medallion
Margin scroll-bearers direct reader’s gaze between scenes

scene_relationships.subject: Christ enthroned receiving homage from four saints or prophets
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Prefigures his earthly entry through gesture of blessing and scroll motif, anticipating fulfillment in bottom scene
visual_connections: Gold background consistent with lower scene
Circular band framing matches lower medallion
Figures wear similar red and blue drapery
White scroll held echoes palm-branch shape below
Gesture of right hand blessing mirrored in lower Christ’s gesture

scene_relationships.subject: Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem with Christ on a donkey, disciples, and kneeling worshippers
visual_connections: Donkey’s gray color echoes elder’s robes above
Palm tree foliage repeats foliate border motifs
Kneeling woman’s white garment recalls white scroll-bands
Haloed figure’s red mantle matches prophet’s robe above
Roundel border design identical to upper frame

visual_continuity: Alternating red and blue garment palette
Consistent halo treatment around sacred figures

content_theme.scene_description: The lower medallion depicts the Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem: centrally seated Christ, haloed and clad in a vermilion mantle over a blue tunic, rides a gray donkey led by two disciples garbed in complementary red and blue drapery. Below, a kneeling woman in white and gold spreads a richly draped cloth beneath the donkey’s hooves. To the right, three spectators, two framed within a crenellated city gate and one standing in a long blue tunic, lift hands in veneration. A tall stylized palm tree with verdant fronds and two angels perched among the leaves occupies the center background, its trunk rising behind the donkey to link foreground and setting. Figures are proportioned hierarchically: Christ largest, disciples slightly smaller, and kneeling worshipper the smallest. Depth is indicated by slight overlap of figures and the receding steps of the city gate. Drapery displays white-lead highlights and minimal hatching. The donkey’s musculature is defined by curved outlines, and the ground line is a simple band of green with white cloud-like scrolls. Facial types are elongated, with almond-shaped eyes, thin noses, and small mouths, characteristic of mid-13th-century Gothic style.

religious: Christ seated on donkey with cruciform halo
Two angels in palm tree foliage
secular: Two disciples leading the donkey, clad in tunics and mantles

natural: Stylized palm tree with foliate fronds

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum leaf from a quaternion gathering; flesh side with fine hair follicle pattern; evenly trimmed with consistent margins (~15 × 10 cm visible)
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent pigment stability with minimal flaking; gold leaf fully burnished; slight toning of red pigments; borders show tiny losses at extremities; no modern retouching visible
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso ground beneath gold leaf
UV-visible brown ink underdrawing matching finished linework
Regular ruling indentation guiding circular medallion placement
Fine punch-work patterns in the gold background
Layered paint application with visible brush texture in drapery

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s piety and wealth
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual noble patron for use as a devotional Book of Hours

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This dual-medallion illumination likely originates from a mid-13th-century Parisian workshop, reflecting the courtly Gothic tradition that flourished under Louis IX. Its production context suggests a private devotional Book of Hours commissioned by a high-status patron, indicated by the lavish use of gold leaf and rare pigments such as azurite. The sequential top-to-bottom narrative underscores typological reading: Christ’s heavenly authority in the upper roundel prefigures his earthly triumphal entry on Palm Sunday below. Stylistically, the work exhibits innovations in spatial layering—evident in overlapping figures and architectural framing—while retaining hierarchical scaling and flattened plane characteristic of Gothic illumination. The foliate borders and micro-architectural cornerpieces denote a sophisticated collaborative atelier practice, with at least two hands evident in the precision of linework and figural modeling. Iconographically, the image conveys theological themes of prophecy fulfillment and divine kingship, linking Old Testament figures or saints in the upper scene to the New Testament event below. Comparatively, it shares compositional traits with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile, particularly in the rhythmic alternation of red and blue drapery and the circular narrative format. Yet, its novel integration of margin scroll-bearers and dynamic palm-tree angels marks a localized innovation within the Parisian illumination tradition.
